description: Go through the proposed steps in order, one at a time.
For each step:
- Check if it is already complete based on current directory state.
- If complete, skip to the next step.
- If not complete, carry out the step.
Before writing code, inspect the directory and files to check if the intended logic/code already exists.
If the code exists, review to verify it meets current expectations.
If deficient, update/enhance as needed.
For any code written:
- Double-check for syntax errors.
- Ensure the code fits well contextually with adjacent code.
- Confirm nothing is missing (e.g., closing parentheses).
Write just enough code to deliver the required feature or fix.
Avoid adding unnecessary code beyond what’s required.
After completing a step, validate it against the original proposal and its intent.
Ask the user if they want to continue before moving to the next step.
Focus only on the current task; avoid changes for any other goals.
Mark the completed step as 'Completed' with a ✔ tick in the plan file.
Identify/apply the appropriate tests for new/modified code.
Add relevant tests to the tests directory/files; create them if none exist.
Run all relevant tests after adding or updating tests.
Tweak program code if tests fail (do NOT tweak test code just to pass).
Confirm that real (not sample) data is being used, unless otherwise specified by the user.
For each code/application error fixed, document the process and insights in 'learnings_from_debugging.md'.
Refer to the 'How to document' section within that .md file for the proper format.
Adhere to all project and user-specified rules throughout.
